tribolium_castaneum.physicalDesc: Adults are shiny dark reddish-brown with a flat body structure, measuring 3.5–4.0 mm in length.
distinguishing: The temple projection in front of the compound eye does NOT exceed the eye level.
Antennae gradually widen toward the tip.
tribolium_castaneum.reproduction: Females lay 300–400 eggs during their lifetime. 3–4 generations per year.
tribolium_castaneum.bioNotes: Eggs are coated with a sticky material and hidden within food sources, making them difficult to detect during storage inspections.

tribolium_confusum.physicalDesc: Dark reddish-brown with a flat body, measuring 3.5–4.0 mm in length.
distinguishing: The temple projection in front of the eye exceeds the eye level.
Last three antennal segments are noticeably wider than the rest.
tribolium_confusum.reproduction: Females lay 300–400 eggs during their lifetime. 3–4 generations per year.
tribolium_confusum.bioNotes: Often confused with T. castaneum due to similar appearance. Distinguished primarily by the temple projection and antennal structure.

sitophilus_granarius.physicalDesc: Dark brown to black, measuring 3–5 mm in length. Has a distinctive snout (rostrum) with strong mandibles.
distinguishing: Small punctures visible on pronotum and elytra.
Cannot fly due to reduced (vestigial) hind wings.
sitophilus_granarius.reproduction: Females lay eggs inside wheat kernels and seal the hole with a gelatinous secretion. 150–300 eggs per female. 3–4 generations per year depending on storage conditions.
sitophilus_granarius.bioNotes: One of the most destructive stored grain pests. The inability to fly means infestations typically spread through movement of infested grain.

sitophilus_oryzae.physicalDesc: Reddish-brown to dark brown, measuring 2.5–4.0 mm in length. Has a snout similar to other weevils.
distinguishing: Small punctures on pronotum and elytra similar to S. granarius.
Unlike S. granarius, the Rice Weevil can fly.
sitophilus_oryzae.reproduction: Females bore into grain kernels to deposit eggs. Multiple generations per year under favorable conditions.
sitophilus_oryzae.bioNotes: A major pest of stored rice, wheat, and other cereals worldwide. Flight capability allows it to infest grain in the field before harvest.

sampleResults.name: Sitophilus granarius (Granary Weevil)
sampleResults.habitat: Grain storage facilities, silos, warehouses, flour mills
sampleResults.diet: Wheat and other stored cereal grains
sampleResults.lifespan: Approximately 4-5 months depending on temperature and humidity
characteristics: Dark brown to black body color
Distinct elongated snout (rostrum) with strong mandibles
Small punctures visible on pronotum and elytra
Cannot fly due to reduced hind wings
Females lay eggs inside wheat kernels and seal the hole with a gelatinous secretion
Produces 3-4 generations per year under suitable storage conditions
sampleResults.funFact: Unlike many other weevils, Sitophilus granarius cannot fly because its hind wings are reduced, yet it remains one of the most destructive stored-grain pests worldwide.
